Years I ago I noticed bed bugs. This is how I eradicated them. 1) I sealed my mattress with a bag, as suggested here. 2) I cleaned all my clothes, sheets etc. 3) I bought four small bowls and put diatomaceous earth in all of them. I then placed each leg of my bed into one bowl. That way when the bugs wanted to climb up to me, they would climb up the bowl and fall into the diatomaceous earth. Every morning I found bugs in the bowls. Within a week they were all dead.
I learned so much about bed bugs I didn't know. Oh and I'm totally with you on cockroachs ðŸª³  nasty little things...

3 years ago bed bugs appeared in my bed and my brother's bed. We finished them off by heating up water and pouring the hot water between the wood (base of the bed) and that's the only way we got rid of them. They are very hateful and sometimes they burn as if you had been burned with something hot.

I just cleaned them manually. Every 5 days (because they hatch in about 7 days) I went through the area of about 4 meters around my bed, vacuumed them, cleaned their eggs and washed all the bed sheets and stuff. Did that for a couple of weeks and soon enough, there were none. Continued searching for them a couple more weeks, just in case. Despite all the talk going around, getting rid of them is actually pretty easy and requires only persistence.

The best way to get rid of bed bugs is a dracula but then you have a bigger problem.
as someone who works in facility maintenance and worked in a hotel, the most common place bed bugs seem to come from is people that live in apartment buildings and condos. they are the hardest places to completely eradicate them from. in a hotel, we would call a pest control company, all fabrics in the room go straight into the dryers and the technicians would dust the entire room with a powder (every crack and crevice including inside the box-spring) and seal the room for 48hrs. after that time we vacuumed up the dust and the bedbugs were completely gone. its hard to do that to an entire building with permanent tenants.
20 04...... Also, sprinkling diatomaceous earth around the feet of the bed is another great defense.
17 37...... Also, in drying climates, the diatomaceous earth will act like razor blades to the joints of the bed bugs, essentially immobilizing them.

Yes, bed bugs can transmit the parasite that causes Chagas disease:  Parasite The parasite that causes Chagas disease is called Trypanosoma cruzi (T. cruzi).  Bed bugs Bed bugs can carry the parasite for up to 97 days, and the pathogen can survive through the molting process between nymphal stages. In one study, researchers fed 3,000 bed bugs T. cruzi-infected mice, and the majority of the bed bugs tested positive for T. cruzi.

I sprayed bed bug spray onto the baseboards of the room, the legs of the bed, and all of the crevices on the bed. I also washed all of the sheets and repeated everything above, as necessary. Guy in prison in the late1880s noticed he was being eaten at night by bed bugs. He saw they were coming from the floorboards and not from the iron and wood plank bed. To fix this every night before bed he would place the four bed legs into tin cups of water preventing the bugs from climbing up the bed legs into the bed.

How I defeated bed bugs. Probably only works for a single person.  A friend I visited to play video games with had bed bugs, but never told me until I mentioned I suddenly got them.  After a month or two of half-hearted attempts with bed bags, washing and vacuuming everything, I just got out my hammock with the metal frame.  I slept on the hammock for a year and they were gone.  They could not climb up the metal, so they apparently starved to death.

Animatic battle remix intro song!
We had bedbug infestation in late 1970s, my mum would empty a flask of dichlofoss spray and leave the home for a day. I remember we needed to do this more than twice.   Later in early 2000s I lived in a flat which had a sudden massive cockroach infestation. I tried the little boxes to get rid of them and there was very little effect. Then I looked at instructions that it actually only covers 4 square meters. So I calculated area of walls and floors in the house and divided by 4, which turned out to be quite a large number, stuck them everywhere. I also bought cockroach chalk and criss crossed the whole flat with it. The cockroaches disappeared pretty soon. As suddenly as they had appeared.
I have experience biting by bed bugs more than three years. Make sure you have none with you. They rapidly increase in number and can hide very well.

I used those little coaster dishes for 4 months.   it's been five years and I've been bed bug free

we had them 2 times, once because I lived in the dorm with them and found out by blood stains on sheets at home only. And then it was too late. The second time is unclear, maybe from some bus or so. Both times we easily killed them by tossing all the mattresses and carpets away + buying some pesticides to spray around. In first case we also removed loads of wallpaper as they were trying to live under that, we do live in old wooden house so there is loads of cracks for them..  They were only in one room, but we fumigated the other room next to it too. Both times we dealt with them successfully. Still have a bit of a phobia from them. I guess there was no massive infestation, so that's why it was easier.

Deep clean, make sure to wipe down all surfaces on your bed including the frame, and vacuum up any bugs. Put all linen and clothes in the hot wash and dryer. Mist all surfaces and mattress with diluted crossfire (read the instructions), re-mist after a month. It's about a days work, but saves you thousands.

how can Yu have them crawl on yu fross
Went to an Airbnb in Chicago about 2 years ago and briefly fell asleep. I woke up maybe 20 minutes later very itchy and I remembered thinking to myself while half asleep "Why am I so itchy with welts on my body, it's the winter time, and there are no mosquitos" and then instantly light bulb went off and I thought "Oh no!! Bed bugs" up until this point in my life I had never been bitten by one. I jumped up and cut the lights on and pulled the blanket back and there they were. About 5-10 of them are full of my blood. My wife was still sleeping heavily in the bed so I pushed her very hard and woke her up and she jumped up quickly. We spent the next 3-4 hours putting all of our clothing and bags in the dryer on a very high setting to ensure we didn't bring anything back home with us. We later went and got a hotel. That experience traumatized me and it was very hard to sleep comfortably in any setting, even now I thoroughly check hotels and things for bed bugs. Those bites are unlike any other bite I have experienced. Mosquito bites usually itch for an hour or so.. Those bed bug bites itched extremely badly for days!! I couldn't stop scratching because they itched so bad. If i remember correctly i had to go get some itch relief cream just to soothe the itch but even that didn't help. I don't see how people can live in infested homes with these things.

7:37 I thought I was bitten
They don't carry or transmit anything??? How do they not transmit AIDS and other blood born diseases.??? That doesn't even seen logical.
Diatomacious earth doesn't just magically suck the water out of bugs (it works on basically all bugs by the way), it's really sharp and jagged at a bug's scale (while being completely harmless to something like a human, or a cat, or a lizard), shredding their exoskeleton as they move around. Like if you walked through a forest of razors, and had razors stuck to you, that shredded through your skin and muscles as you moved. The dessication aspect just speeds up the death (I would imagine, I don't know for sure)  Also, diatomacious earth isn't going to generate a selective evolutionary pressure- bugs aren't going to develop an immunity to it like pesticides would do for them. This is because it's not a chemical doing a very highly specific thing to them which could be avoided if they changed X, Y, or Z metabolic process by a slight amount... it's a physical deterrent. It's physically shredding the bugs. They fundamentally can't get around that, unless they somehow evolved to change their exoskeletons out for endoskeletons, with the squishy stuff on the outside. Which... that'd take a very, very, very long time, millions of years at the very least, exoskeletons are deeply fundamental aspects of bugs.
so evolution selects bed bugs because they don't transmit disease and evolution selects mosquitos because they do transmit disease.  Got it.

bed bugs do carry diseases tho
Just to maybe clarify something: the testing process shown in the video is useless and proves actually nothing. I'm not calling you out on making this up, and i'm very sure that the professor shown in the video uses better methods of testing that those shown. Just to point out the problem: the only thing you've done with the different test setups is prove that they move towards either one of these locations. I would've loved to see a few examples of the same experiment built up with 2 times the same attraction in both corners. Otherwise, you can only prove that they do seem to go for one of those targets, which could also be caused by them "hunting" in groups and just following each other.  Also, the experiments could've been built up way too close to each other, with the ultrasonic thingy just scrambling noise into each of the other experiments.  I do know that you educate people. I do know that you try to be entertaining while doing so. But this just teaches newbies in science the wrong ways to go about testing their own biases. Without the information from the professor, these experiments added nothing of value. Even more so since you weren't even presenting them for over a minute, which probably should already show us that you either didn't think about it too much, or that you don't want us to think about those experiments either, and just give us the straight up facts. Which would also be okay, but then ... please ... why pretend with all this "scientific" testing?  I still do love your work, which is why i criticize this. Keep on doing what you're doing, you're having a positive impact on the world, and that is what matters after all.
:O MARK ROBER MY COUSIN IN LAW USED TO WORK IN THAT LAB HE WAS THE BENGALI DUDE

Thank you for your help ðŸ˜¢ðŸ˜ŠðŸ˜Š i have got my answer
I remember when bed bugs were so rare in most of the USA that we didn't realize that they ever truly existed.  I used to give tours at historic sights and we told the public the rhyme "sleep tight, don't let the bed bugs bite" didn't reflect the fact that there were species of bugs that evolved to feed on us while we sleep,  but instead the rhyme originated in the fact that mattresses were sacks stuffed with outdoor bugs who might nip us for reasons other than feeding on us. I was never corrected back in the 1990's after speaking with people from all over the country.  I didn't learn bed bugs were real until I lived in an apartment that had them.

Bed bug feces contain a deadly disease causing agent called Trypanosoma Cruzi.  Scratching bed bug bites can drive the protozoans into your blood stream, leading to an infection called Chagas disease.

People like me who have been through infestations frequently suffer from paranoia surrounding them, and are hyper-vigilant when it comes to looking for the first signs of an infestation, but those of us with little to no reaction to bites don't catch the most important one. Ew! Cimex Lectularius. Crossfire worked wonders for me more than once. Bedbugs are most common in homeless shelters, apartments where homeless frequent, and some motels/hotels. They could even be on your flight or anywhere people sit for a while be it a bus or some office. My grandma who grew up in the 1930's great depression said, sleep tight don't let the bed bugs bit, for she and lots of people were homeless during that time. The difference between then and today is they were more united and patriotic though suffered bed bugs, filth, and hardships. They got through it going on united as Americans to make America the great country we've known since WW2. I loved hearing her experiences on holidays as kid about they were safe sleeping in big city parks such as Veterans Park in downtown Saint Louis, Missouri which is a homeless park today though unsafe and scary.

love from GJ 18 india
This video is cute, but bedbugs are a nightmare that literally drives some people into an institution.  Long after people have actually rid their home of bedbugs, they can have welts and sores appear just from the stress of worrying about them.  People have abandoned homes entirely, and even abandoned all of their possessions - literally getting into a taxi in fresh underwear and leaving everything.  Bedbugs can lay dormant inside electronic devices.  Superheating your home rarely works.  There are only a handful of dogs in the World trained to hunt down the nesting spots of bedbugs, and even the fanciest hotels in the world have secretly gutted the walls of entire floors in an attempt to rid themselves of an infestation.  Bedbugs know when you are sleeping, and they can smell this from 60' away.

I work in pestcontrol, my company sprays strong insecticide with residual on peopleâ€™s mattresses, couches and any furniture in the house (not where people have contact with the fabric ). We also do a crack and crevasse treatmeant. Usually takes a few services to get rid of them.

You would not believe how incredibly small they can be. I have been bitten,but being incredibly sensitive,interrupted it. Knocked it off my arm,and searched for it. After about 5 minutes I f not finding it,I grabbed a magnifying glass,and there it was,the same size as a speck of dirt or dust,very unnerving. To flush out anymore,grabbed my hairdryer and went along the seamed of mattressb and outlets...was fortunate and found no other bugs.
I had a moderate infestation. Panic every night knowing I was going to get bit. Exterminator wanted $2k to spray, then I found a product called cimexa. It's like diatomaceous earth but more concentrated crushed silica. It was super effective and no sign of them after a month and almost a year and a half later and they've stayed gone.

In Russia we have a very effective way to combat bedbugs.  In winter in Russia, the temperature drops to -50Â°, you need to turn off the heating in the house and open the window, and go to relatives for 3 days.  When you return all the bedbugs will be dead!

Mark, do one about ticks !!!
I had bedbugs a few years back.  We got them from a hotel.  We should have known something was up when we had to leave in the middle of the night because my son was having an incontrollable asthma attack.  We found the little blood suckers in his room about 3 months later.  It was bad.  Not much was on the market to treat them, so I did some testing myself.  Nothing this scientific, but with clear results.  I captured 10 bedbugs at a time, put them in a plastic container and added the treatment as desired.    Diatomaceous earth does work well, but so does boric acid  or borax, but at a fraction of the cost.  Sprinkle the carpet and baseboards with either of the 3, and the effect is the same.  The cheap powdered laundry detergent works well too, but not as well.  Boric acid had the best success.  I did find a combination of pesticides does work with a residual effect.  It's Cyonara 9.7 (Lambda-cyhalothrin 9.7%), Bifenthrin, and Permethrin.  These work slightly different from each other, so a generational immunity is unlikely, and are each safe for indoor use.  The Cyonara has a pleasant cherry blossom smell.  Just steam, spray, them put down powder.  Those little blood suckers were gone in a few weeks.  Given their long food intake intervals, we still see one on occasion, but they are typically already dieing.

RUBBING ALCHOHOL 90%

So What is the best remedy to destroy bedbugs. Not difficult things we life in holland.
I worked as a pest and hygiene inspector / training specialist on cruise ships, and bed bugs multiply at an incredible rate. Also, they often live behind the tops of curtains, paintings and mirrors. They can remain dormant for many months, awakening only when they detect human heat. If their dwelling is empty for a very long time, bed bugs will eat each other, as they see each other as protein. Therefore, they can be extremely hard to completely eliminate. If you're ever affected by them, call in specialists as soon as possible.

This is the first time I have seen a bed bug.  The stages they go through were very helpful as well.  Must be able to recognise them if staying in a hotel while traveling.  I was born in 1950 and was shocked by the statistics that at that time, 1 in 3 homes had bed bugs.  Our family and extended family never had them in our houses.  I saw my first Cockroach when I lived in an apartment house with other students.  I did not know what kinds of bugs were in my bathtub until someone told me.  After graduation, my father did not let me bring my things home.  I understand why.  My father said the south had the largest Cockroaches when he was stationed there for a while in the early 1940s.  Thank you for the hot water/steam and diatomaceous earth tips, just in case.

"Evolutionary advantage," he said. One more item to support the contention that evolutionism has set true science back HUNDREDS OF YEARS. Chrysanthemum powder applied to bedding in hotels & similar places of hospitality kept them in check for hundreds of years, DDT reduced them to the point where many people grew up thinking there were no such things , but proved so toxic that it was removed from the market, & in just a few decades, they've become a worldwide problem again.

Thank you excellent money saving info. I had bed bugs when I lived at The Strand Palace hotel London In late 70's. The bites were like huge eggs and they preferred my chest and neck. I had the room fumigated and one was under my pillow next morning. I put pots of DDT under each bed leg and immediately a bug was in the liquid. I haven't come across them since than goodness but do get booklice. They, booklice, love the feathers of rescue birds. I steam everything now.

My father once told me that during his military service, he was assigned to a garrison where he encountered a room infested with bed bugs. Determined to find a solution, the next day he headed to the kitchen and grabbed four large empty canned food containers. Filling them with water, he placed each bed leg into a can. To his dismay, he discovered the following days that the bugs had changed their strategy. Instead of climbing up the bed legs, they had found a way to reach the ceiling and then strategically dropped onto the bed! Truly amazing.
We've been using DE and steamers for years. Imagine all the pollutants & money wasted when nature does know best.

I got bed bugs a few years ago and my wife and I went scortched earth. We moved the bed away from the wall, got bed bug bed wraps, used the powder, threw away and binned up a ton of items, washed our clothes and bedding morning and night. I hate to say it but we also wasted a ton of money the sprays. In the end we were victorious... until we started moving and we found some that were trapped in a spot 'hybernating' and we lost our S*%T again. It was much easier the second time  Do yourself a favor and just preemptively get those bed bug covers for any matress you have.

Numa forma mais rustica, a raquete para mosquitos tambÃ©m funciona, ao menos para identificar que hÃ¡ percevejos; Estenda a cama, aguarde uns minutos, com a luz apagada golpeie com a raquete a superfÃ­cie da cama, se houver "estalos" haverÃ¡ percevejos.
What works even better than all of his suggestions is cinnamon powder. Bedbugs absolutely HATE cinnamon. My wife and I got rid of bedbugs that she brought back from her month in Macau by simply putting Ceylon cinnamon in all of our food for a while so they wouldn't bite us, and Ceylon cinnamon under the mattress, on the floor under the bed and around the legs of the bed. Make sure to only ingest the Ceylon variety of cinnamon because the other kinds have a significant amount of an oil in them called Coumarin that is highly toxic to the liver and will cause liver damage over time.
Just found this video and I'm glad I did!  I've been dealing with a mild (as in my bed didn't look nearly as bad as the moderately-infested room did when I first found them) infestation in my apartment for about a year now, and unfortunately I'm among the 50% of people who get nasty red welts from bites.  Sprays worked well for a bit, but I suspect they aren't doing as well anymore, and now I know why.  But sprinkling with the diatomaceous earth alongside spraying seems to do quite well, and I'm on my way to purchasing a handheld steamer. x3  Thanks for the interesting entomological information as well!
I got them from the hospital when I gave birth. Regret packing a bag with a change of clothing and supplies, should have just gone commando.  My mom was a lab tech at a different hospital. She said hospitals are number one hot spot in our area. Dad works on houses and keeps a bucket of diatomaceous earth he uses as both powder and a spray. It is your best friend.

Well, the best solution wasn't mentioned - If your house is hyper-clean, you won't have any natural predators to eat the bed bugs or especially their eggs. What you need are the small house spiders that thrive in homes that are not perfectly cleaned, or keep a compost bucket that will breed fruit flies and other small critters that will feed your little spiders in the meantime. The only people with bed bugs will have pesticide-perfect homes, and they get whacked again and again. (Even worse with clothes moths.)  Nature is very unkind to pesticide users.

I have read a lot about bed bugs.  The truth as I know it is the bed bug puts an anaesthesia into you initially so you don't feel the bite.  That makes sense bc Mark didn't feel the bites.  But the bug expert did not seem to know this.  The reaction to the bites come later.  He would get red marks like 24 hrs later, I bet.  Also, bites come in twos.  Usually, there are 2 red marks about an inch apart.  So if you see one bite, most likely you'll see 2 bitemarks.

The way DE works is it puts cuts in the bed bugs waxy cuticle, which all bugs have on the outside of the exoskeleton.  They donâ€™t heal like we do with our skin.  Once that armor is pierced, they slowly dry out/leak out until they are â˜ ï¸

Our grandmothers in the Middle East get rid of bedbugs and lice by placing clothes and bedding in a large metal bowl, adding an appropriate amount of water, then placing the clothes in the water and turning on the fire until the water begins to boil for a short period, not exceeding a minute.  This method is fast, effective and very cheap

@France
I wound up with them in my van some years back and my house and had a really bad reaction. Severe itching and welts for days. Found the P.F. Harris products to be very effective. Sprayed the car every day for about a month with the egg and resistant bed bug killer spray, and used diatomaceous earth for the house. I keep traps under the bed legs, never a single bug since. I actually carry these when I'm traveling and spray and treat every room I stay in before bringing in any luggage, I compulsively use the luggage rack and immediately wash any travel clothes when I get home. I really hate these bugs.

Some things he didnâ€™t mention - they will adapt to your sleep schedule to feed whenever you are sleeping, and will even attack while youâ€™re awake. If you prevent them from climbing the bed to get to you, they will climb the wall and onto the ceiling, and drop onto the bed. If you take public transportation, you can get them from other passengers - especially in a tight bus or subway train. This is the most adaptable bug you can imagine.

I got bedbugs once and it was impossible to get rid of them.  It's awful it feels like you have a disease.  The only way I could get rid of them was to throw away my bed, clean up the room and get a new bed.  They are so strong and hard to find.  I would try to capture them sometimes and put them in a ziplock bag.  I couldn't even tell they were biting me and I very rarely saw them crawling around.
Been dealing with them on and off for many years - Someone brought them into my son's middle school classroom. It takes constant vigilance of everything Mark said. Even after you think they're gone. Stay with it for a month or two!

13 or 14 years ago we had this problem! Purple can^ did work then and also I used plastic drop cloth taped across the carpeted floor and to the top of the baseboards - between that and THROWING out every upholstered piece of furniture and hydrogen peroxide in a spray bottle to spray anything and everything everywhere for a few weeks took care of the problem - new mattress's were the biggest expense ~ but I'd rather have nothing than have BED BUGS!

To whoever may find this useful. As Mark demonstrated, they can climb in to your bed via your beds contact points with the ground. Iâ€™m currently dealing with a situation where my roommate got them and Iâ€™m trying to prevent them. I just put very sticky double sided tape on the legs of my bed. I also made sure that my bed wasnâ€™t touching any walls, in hope that if they try to climb the legs theyâ€™ll get stuck. Not sure if this will even work or be any help, but it makes sense in my head I guess. Hope it works or helps someone out!

W/ diatomaceous earth I use a fluffy paintbrush for walls/surfaces or a broom for floors. Just tap off excess and apply an invisible layer. I can attest this works for ALL crawling bugs...great for pantry and kitchen areas, too. Get food grade if you have pets/small children.

Had these in my 7 room hotel once way back in time. I turned the electricity off, filled a garden pump sprayer with 90% ipa and hosed the place down while masked and wrapped in a tyvek suit. Every seam, every fiber, corner and shadow. Resulting in a giant entomologist specimen jar. Sealed up the place, came back to look for signs of life the next day. The enemy was dead en-masse. No survivors. Sprayed it one more time to be sure. Total time spent was under two hours. So gross and unforgettable.

I bought a lovely used couch, not even thinking about how it might contain bedbugs. It did, and they spread all over the house. It was awful. We used diatomaceous earth and steaming, washing, bagging. We pulled up the carpets and switched to wood floors. The thing that finally cleared the house is when it got down to about 8 degrees Fahrenheit. We put all the furniture outside for three days. The bugs all died, and the eggs froze, so it stopped the cycle. It was a happy day. We still keep all of our mattresses covered and are now super cautious about buying used furniture and careful when traveling, but I will say when all else fails, freezing cold actually works, too.

Also, when they have a small colony going, after a night of feeding they will send a few as scouts to wander up to 50 ft from their "home" location in search gor new humans, then come all the way back home before dawn. They have internal clovks and thet know when to get out of sight before daylight breaks, or even before you wake up if you regularly wake up before dawn.  After a night of scouting, those scouts spend the next night feeding whipe others scout. This is why if youre in a house with multiple people and some are getting bit, but other occupants think they arent in their room, they are wrong! Everyone in the house has them, but some people just dont have an alergic reaction.

Alcohol works great.  I have cleaned carpets and whole rooms using this.  And alcohol evaporates so you lose the smell after a couple of days.  For  bed legs and such use tuna cans... wash and dry the cans and put mineral oil in them and use them to keep bugs from crawling up the legs of furniture. Only time I had those was because of living in a duplex and the people next door were absolute pigs. Luckily caught it early on, had to move everything off the floor, clothes were all washed in hot water, dried. Meanwhile we did visual search for as many as we could find, sprayed them with alcohol. After all was clean we sprinkled the carpets with diatomaceous earth and opened one of those spray bombs in the bedroom before leaving for the weekend. Came back and they were all dead.

Kind of ironic in that the most effective means or eradicating roaches is to use borax mixed with diatomaceous earth which is available just about wherever insecticides are sold.  So far, roaches have not found a way to become resistant to the stuff.  They are usually gone in a couple of weeks.  It but it is messy because it is spread as a dust on counter tops, floors against the counters, under stove, along stove walls, under refrigerators, etc., but it can be cleared out with a vacuum cleaner.

TLDR; don't use chemicals. Spot treat with diatomaceous Earth, AND call a professional who uses heat treatments. DIY application of chemicals are just speeding up the evolution towards a bed bug overlord scenario ;) A professional will likely be able to tell if they're coming from an adjacent apartment because over-infestation (they will branch out if their area gets too busy) or if they've just hitchhiked on your clothes.

No insect cares for ultrasonic sound, not bed bugs, not mosquitos, not flies, not ants. I don't know who came up with that myth but you cannot fight any kind of insect using ultrasonic sound. Insects don't notice that sound at all of they will but just won't care for it. In every scientific test those devices just did nothing at all.

I had bedbugs for 2-3 months at my house courtesy of a house guest who also had them. Had the windows open. Vacuumed a day after that making sure I didnâ€™t breathe fumes. But after 2 weeks of this rigorous regimen they all died. The guy next door (they were semi detached cottages), had just about everything infesting him and his house, and is probably the reason why the last people had moved because the house was beautiful and beautifully decorated. I soon found out because I saw fleas jumping from the neighbour onto my son and Great Dane and I am fairly sure despite having had the place treated bed bugs could access my half of the building through the joint attics ( There were partitions but not solid ones, and I think they came from the ventilation system.  I was really upset about having to leave there but it wasn't something I could have lived with.  Great to know steam, hoovering and diatomaceous earth are best at controlling them because that is an experience I don't want to repeat.
11:22 i dont have bed bugs
Silica effects ants too
Back in 2011 i lived in a place that had bedbugs and i heard about the diatomaceous earth. I put it everywhere, but saw no results after a few months. So i wanted to do a controlled test. I got a lockable plastic bin, 12x8x4 inches, and filled the bottom inch with the DE, and coated the walls with talcum powder so they couldnt try to escape. I captured 50 recently fed bedbugs and put them in the bin. I would check on it every day. I added no more bedbugs to the test. Three whole months later, i noticed that all the bugs were still alive, along with a heck of a lot of nymphs and eggs. I took the bin outside and found only 12 confirmed dead adults. Many nymphs were dead, but the rest were still alive. All of the bugs were white from being covered with the DE, but it seemed to not affect them. There were some young ones that had molted to one stage, and discovered the only way they could have done this was to cannibalize the adults. I was amazed that the adults who had died were not just dry, but horrendously damaged. When i moved out of that place, i put all my stuff in a Uhaul truck, and had the exterminators keep the truck at their facility to tent it and heat it over the weekend, then had the truck professionally washed. All i can say was that the bills for the truck tenting and for keeping the truck for so long cost more than $2,000 each. But i had no more bugs after that! Heating is the ONLY THING that works.
Great stuff as usual! Do one for cockroaches too!

You don't repel beg bugs. You terminate the whole colony in a single afternoon. Use a pesticide with nerve agent that explicitly states it's effective even against larva on furniture and every nook, even outlets. Then you use lime for the walls and every hole you can inject into. 90 C wash ALL clothing, throw out useless appliances, what you really want to keep you have to dismantle and check. If you don't want another wave of infestation you need the nuclear option, woe to anyone living in an apartment and having that one bad neighbor.

Lived with in laws for one month. Family was getting bit by bed bugs and in laws wouldnt do anything. They said they already threw out numerous mattresses. Had to resolve the issue myself fpr the room we stayed in. Went to walmart, bought a few mattress covers for bwd wetting. Sealed the mattresses up after spraying with bug spray. Wrapped the bed post legs with duck tape reversed with sticky side out. Seemed to have worked. Didnt have any issues with the bed bugs for the remainder of the month. That first few days, they ravaged us. That goodness it wasnt our stuff. Our belongings were in storage. Moved 3 times since living with in laws, haven't had begbugs since. 19:29 - Trust a person who has never had bedbugs to give bad advice.  That cover you are showing now, and those like it, a synthetic cloth with Velcro zipper covers, act like the perfect nesting material for bedbugs (The Velcro was especially infested!).You MAY prevent the interior mattress from being infected, so long as you NEVER open that cover again.  Don't bet on it though. The prime material is PLASTIC with a plastic fine zipper like the ziplock bags.  It may feel like cheap medical material, but it offers no purchase for bedbugs to even move across, let alone try to nest.

When I had to fight an infestation I designed a co2 trap that was very effective. I took about 3 bottles of water, emptied half. Poked holes in the top. Put in yeast and sugar, stirred it around. Taped them together. Put them in a bowl with talc covering the sides, put a piece of cloth leading in, and put a plastic shopping bag on top. It smelled yeasty and unpleasant but it absolutely attracted a ton of them. It helped me, perhaps that can help someone here.

I worked for a company that bought out a bed big control company. Heat is by far the only sure way to eradicate bed bugs in all various stages of their life. Heat every surface of the home to 130+ degrees and they will ALL perish within minutes. You also have to treat all cracks and crevices they could possibly escape to with dust insecticides like baseboards, power outlets, etc.

what...
I'm not sure about bed bugs, but many insects are attracted to electromagnetic fields.  I had heard this and we confirmed it with pillbugs in a highschool science experiment testing their preferences.  My friend I was helping had almost 90% of the pillbugs around the electrified grid, while others students with water, dirt, heat, cold light, UV etc were getting 10-20% differences.  It was rather astonishing that it worked so well, especially since we had it set up almost like a bug zapper and it was shocking them.  I had this further confirmed as an appliance repairman when house after house if there was any bug infestation - especially cockroaches - I would find them nesting in the control panels, main boards, and power boards of the appliances.  Anyway, the point is while you may not be able to steam your alarm clock or other bedside electronics, you can check them for signs of bed bugs.  Also, silicon dioxide is non-conductive so you can probably safely dust most electronics with no moving parts.
Do these methods also apply to fleas? Had a feral cat move in under my workshop and lay some kittens there - now there's fleas galore!

Its funny how bed bug infestation increased once Diazinon was restricted for general purchase by US law. I own a small pest control business, and LOVE this video! Bed Bugs are a pain in the a$$, and the wallet.
My family and I suffered with bed bugs for a year and a half. We tried everything. Sprays, foggers, essential oils, freezing our clothes and blankets, everything. They all failed. I spent $12 on a bag of diatomaceous earth, and dusted it all over the walls, floor, the carpet in my closet, on the bed and frame and bought mattress covers. Their reign of terror was over within 2 weeks. Hundreds of dollars, hours, and a couple exterminator consults wasted because no one told me about crushed up sea shells.

I almost consider myself a bed bug expert, not entirely, but I learned way too much about them after very apparently being bitten by one at an Airbnb I was staying in. Once I realized the bites across my thigh were likely from a bed bug, I went into complete meltdown mode and did everything--and then some--to prevent tracking them home with me. I was paranoid AF for YEARS after the incident. Put cups on my bed legs for two years. White bed linens only. Haven't stay in a hotel since. I became literally nuts and got what the bedbug community calls, "head bugs." When you just cannot let go of it or think they're around all of the time anyway. But I am here at this because I opened an Amazon package that had a weird red squished thing in the box that, when I took a picture of it, looked like it could be a squished bed bug. Freaking out. Threw the packet contents back into the package. Threw the box outside. Vacuumed, discarded vacuum contents, Figuring out how to return it, but most likely will just wrap in a plastic bag and return to UPS, because Amazon won't just let me throw it away. Either way, I am trying to see my head on and not lose it. Hoping it was not a bed bug. Hoping that if it was, it was just that one that got in and got squished. Hoping I did not trail anything inside, and hoping this video makes me feel like I'll be okay.

Worked in public housing ~6 years ago and bedbugs were a constant problem. Exterminator told me that the chemical they used to use worked great, but was extremely carcinogenic so they had to switch to weaker stuff which the bugs are basically immune to now. Eventually we switched to the heat treatments and those seemed to work well, especially considering that the traditional treatments involved a lot of cleaning which most of the tenants hardly ever did.  Funniest part was we had this one lady who was basically a stereotypical crazy hippy who swore by diatomaceous earth. We all basically laughed it off but turns out she was the true galaxy brain all along.

Diatomaceous earth doesn't dessicate insects directly. Being sharp and tiny, it cuts into their waxy cuticle which is responsible for sealing in their internal moisture, and they meet their dehydrated fate in that way ðŸ¦Ÿ

As a licensed pest professional in Arizona, I greatly appreciate this video.  I spent years watching people trying to "fix" bedbugs themselves.  The methods often caused damages, self-poisonings, and extensive money spent on ineffective materials/techniques.  The worst part was the "my friend" told me syndrome that caused even more problems.  No matter how many times I tried, the extreme levels of panic and mis-information made the matters even more difficult.  It is always best to be preventative, take time to find out about the bedbugs in the area, and understand that not all methods work in certain areas around the US.  When in doubt, call a professional group that focuses on education and service.

17:13 - anyone who actually understand what diatomaceous earth is, which apparently Mark did not when first going in, while yes the silicon can absorb water, it is ALSO that the mineral is razor sharp at a microscopic level. It shreds the protective enzymes around an insects body, even the eggs, causing them to suffocate to death and dry out.

I dealt with bedbugs for roughly a year, tried all the products mentioned except the powder that actually works of course lucky me. I tried steaming everything for them but that quickly felt like a futile task steaming every crevice in my house so I looked into professional help but that was thousands of dollars so I looked into heaters and found a company that sales a kit with a heater, fan, and large gauge extension cords for about $1500 then set it up and heated one room each day until i had gone through every room and have been clear of any bugs since then.

Years I ago I noticed bed bugs. This is how I eradicated them. 1) I sealed my mattress with a bag, as suggested here. 2) I cleaned all my clothes, sheets etc. 3) I bought four small bowls and put diatomaceous earth in all of them. I then placed each leg of my bed into one bowl. That way when the bugs wanted to climb up to me, they would climb up the bowl and fall into the diatomaceous earth. Every morning I found bugs in the bowls. Within a week they were all dead.

One thing you are missing is, the moment you get home and you think you might have bed bugs, throw all your cloths in the dryer, including your shoes; cook them.  Also immediately get a hot shower, I once watched 5 fully grow bugs wash off my body and go down the drain. Also wake up in the middle of the night, rip all the bedding off as quickly as possible; including the pillows ball it up and don't let it touch the floor throw those in the dryer as well you will see cooked bugs in your lint screen or in the dryer itself.

Couple corrections: Diatoms are microscopic critters. They're not actually "crushed" to make diatomaceous earth. They live in water, so it's basically a matter of raising them, then evaporating the water.  Second, if an item cannot be subjected to heat, you can also freeze it, though that takes longer.  I am surprised you didn't look at bedbug sniffing dogs, btw!

I have severe PTSD as well as severe hypersensitivity which I gained as a defense mechanism to Rocky mountain spotted tick fever that I got at age 9, and almost diedâ€¦  Afterwards I would always feel all bloodsuckers when they bit me!!  This made for living with bedbugs completely miserable but at the same time it made me a human radar for being able to tell you if you have them or not!!  Because keep in mind, you can have bedbugs for up to a year before you even know that you have them because of the neurotoxin in their saliva that numbs the feeling of the bite for most people as well as the fact that theyâ€™re nocturnal when their numbers are still moderate, thereby they do not come out much but once their numbers of population gets so high then they will come out during the day and you will see them at which point it will be impossible to not know that you have them!! We thoroughly check everywhere for bed bugs in hotels or airbnb's. With our luggage in the bathtub. If I'm really being a stickler, in our underwear so even that set of clothes is safe lol. Dirty clothes go in Ziploc bags to try a little more to keep them out of suitcases.
Don't use hotel luggage racks without checking them out first. Some people pick their suitcases up off the floor or bed and put them on the luggage rack.
I am reactive to most biting insects-- the area of bites for just about anything will become really red, swollen, and itchier than anything else I can compare it to.  The only bugs I react 'normally' to when bitten by them are spiders and mosquitoes.  I was the reason my relatives found out they had a bedbug infestation, as they did not react to the bites at all.  I spent one night there, and I was covered in bites.  Oddly enough, I put deodorant on certain areas after realizing (as I had to spend more than one night), and the bugs did not bite again in the areas that were covered.  Just like me, they hate the taste of the stuff!  XD

I'm consistently surprised how few people know about Diatemaceous earth.  It's honestly fantastic not just for Bedbugs, but for roaches, ants, spiders, really anything that creepy crawlies around and has an exoskeleton.   I had a german cockroach infestation years ago from a neighbor and I used the yellow sprayer in this video and sprayed every part of my house to the point that it looked like a bag of flour exploded ( light dusting, not piles like Mark says) and it really, really helped.  Worked for a friend of mine as well when her house suddenly became ground zero for ants one summer. Dusting around the ingress they were using and it slowed to a trickle, then stopped entirely. She did have to keep re-dusting the area tho.

One other thing too, if you are searching for their nests, don't just look down low, as I found a huge nest in the folds at the top of my drapes....sneaky little buggers.
I had a medium sized infestation, and I didn't steam anything, but I encased my mattress, box spring and pillows in those covers, then put down a slippery plastic container within a container, with talcum powder, and placed each bed post inside them, and pushed the bed to the centre of the room. They were at that point unable to get to me, which through lack of food thinned their numbers considerably. I added the offense later with the dia... earth, which eventually got rid of the rest.

Very interesting... Diatomaceous earth is also effective against scorpions.  With scorpions it cuts their exoskeleton and their dehydrate within a couple days.  Not sure about the "sticking" aspect that is referenced in this video.  That may be the case w/ bedbugs, but w/ scorpions it cuts them.  Apparently just like bedbugs, this is ultimately better than most advertised sprays/repellants/pesticides when it comes to scorpions.

Once when I've moved in to a flat which was previously bedbug infested and poorly dealt with and it recurred. It took me several months to actually notice it as initially i did not get any skin reaction but later on my body started reacting to bites. Hotels are an underrated source of bed bugs. I worked in pest control. Even a brand new hotel can have bed bug problems...  Not just the cheap gross places.
Here in south india, we simply put out the mattresses, bedsteads, cots (charpoys) and blankets in the HOT SUN FOR A COUPLE OF HOURS. Spraying kerosene in the remaining nooks and crevices of the house does the job. Doing this frequently gets rid of these pests completely.

Pro tip: when putting in a new floor, before the baseboard is put on, fill diatomaceous earth all around the edges of the room under where the baseboard will go, between the flooring and the wall (works with carpet as well - just fill the space between the carpet tack strip and the wall).  This will take care of bedbugs, ants, sow bugs, etc.

Fun fact:  "Traumatic insemination" is a lot more common amongst insects than you think.  Bed bugs are definitely not the only species that does this.  However, they *are* the only species that reproduces *exclusively* utilizing this method.  Male-on-male action has also been observed.

I had a mild infestation which can go to ultra critical in a very short time......I have a simple protocol to get rid of these little suckered....you have to first get mattress covers and before you seal that up dust inside with diatomaceous earth, then you should wash and dry with high heat all the sheets and clothes . Then you need to dust everywhere in the rooms where you sleep with diatomaceous earth, and all over the mattress where you sleep and effectively make yourself the bait......this can take up to 3 weeks depending how bad the infestation you have is

Ok so here is a simple trick we do to get rid of them at nearly 100% mortality rate- aluminium phosphide. It comes in a tube that consists of 30 tablets, usually used as a pesticide in fields or store rooms. Use few tablets in a room, close all doors and windows, leave it closed for about 24-48 hours. Done, every bug is dead, not just bed bugs. It will leave a nasty smell that you have to wipe out after cleaning the room. This stuff is deadly for humans too, so use with caution. If nothing works, try this, this will be the last remedy you'll ever need. Not to mention those tablets are super cheap.

Another simple truth about bed bugs. If you have them in your bed, you will also have them anywhere you sit, including the toilet. Also, D.E. is more than a dessicant. The structure of the dust is very sharp and shreds them, generally within 48 hours. Other wise it would take a week to dry them out, 2 days longer than their feeding cycle of 5 days.

I'll start off by saying I've done some really weird things in my life, one being keeping roaches and spaghetti jars I had 30 samples I wanted to see how long they would survive without eating how many babies each contained how many male supposed to females etc but the weirdest was going to the laundromat and capturing bed bugs and keeping them in pill bottles seeing how long I could keep them without eating how much they would eat just so I could learn about them on my own and I had one for 7 months with no food--I've also kept normal things like caterpillars, that eventually molted into butterflies/moths..ppl say those that do this are weird/gross but that is how we learn...

Those stats on bedbugs are unfounded. All I saw was that "1/5 people had or know someone that has them" and that "1/5 households is affected by bedbugs".
Sorry that this comment is critical: Love Mark, but all field studies and lab studies, including Dr. Wang's, have found Cimexa to be much more effective than diatomaceous earth. Also, local conditions can impact what is and isn't effective. Like humidity. Like people unable to de-clutter. I don't like toxic chemical solutions, or high-priced solutions, but treating bed bug infestations is not one-size-fits-all.

My grandmother's thinking was that birds carry bedbugs, she was very careful to keep all birds away from the house.  Dust baths of diatomaceous earth were kept available to all poultry.  It seems to be borne out because of the three houses I have found locally with bedbugs all have someone who works in chicken houses.  I have been asked to check over a dozen homes and found three with significant problems that were eventually eradicated.  One took a while because they were not convinced diatomaceous earth would work and didn't want to heat treat. They spent a lot on bombs and spraying and even a pest control  company that was ineffective.

Use cymexa rather than diatomaceous earth - cymexa is pure silica dust and is the only sure thing that works. And call an exterminator, because you can never get rid of them yourself. Orkin came to my small apartment 9 times after I used every product on the market. And it's hard work - took us 6 months - and I'm traumatized for the rest of my life.
There's also bat bugs, that look similar to bed bugs. They come of off birds and bats, and are yellow. Not to mention there are lice on most birds. So if you have an attic, you may want to check it especially for dead bats.

im eating while watching this LOL
I moved to an apartment here in Florida that was infested. Their hive was on an outlet in the bedroom. I ended up getting rid of them by using the diatomaceous earth around the house, encasing my mattress in one of those covers and bought the traps (the thing where they can't get out) and put the bed legs on them with diatomaceous earth. Landlords in Florida just have to show they are doing something, so sending someone to spray shows they did something and that's it. The next pest control guy that came to spray after I had followed those steps, told me what I did would work better than whatever he sprayed would do.

Bed bugs are miserable to have. They can go 9 months without a blood meal. Then if they snacked on you, you'll have to deal with their babies next week. You can get rid of them, but you'll need the powder and a spray peicicide (forgers don't work well). Vacuuming all the time and heat treating clothing helps, but its not enough.

A small correction: Bed bugs do, in fact, transmit disease. 2 particularly nasty ones are chagas and bartonellosis. The easiest way to get rid of them, in my experience, was (food grade) diatomaceous earth. I dusted my entire apartment, and applied poison dust all around the bottoms of the walls where they met up with the floor. I let it sit for a few weeks, then vacuumed it all up. They never came back.

Bro I was watching this in my bed
I had to clear two infestations myself. The methods chosen by me, diatomaceous earth in bedpost coasters combined with putting it in the corners of the baseboards, and then taping over all the baseboards with packaging tape. This trapped them in the baseboards with the diatomaceous earth. I also got a plastic impermeable mattress bag. Finally, we covered the pet beds in diatomaceous earth and put all beds and cloth furniture high on shelves after doing this. Exterminators in northern Utah have no idea how to handle bed bugs and they failed to experiment the two times we tried the professional route.

As far as I know here in Finland people once upon a time used to get rid of them by putting what you could not wash easily in a sauna when it was heated. The other way was using winter temperatures when it got to minus 20 Celcius or colder. Either leave things out, or in an unheated outbuilding, or sometimes move somewhere else and let the whole house get cold for days when it was a smaller building. Since both were easier to use in the countryside and by people who had their own saunas and houses bedbugs were supposedly more of a problem in towns and cities.

As someone who grew up with the horror of bedbugs, I was scared to watch this video.  But I'm glad I did, awesome video Mark
You completely missed mentioning the reason you don't feel bed bugs bite is because they inject you with an anesthetic. It can take hours to wear off and when it does, it can itch like crazy but since it's been hours, it's hard to connect what bit you and when.  I got rid of mine with a combination of encasements on the mattress and boxsprings, vacuuming a lot, washing sheets a lot, traps on the bed legs and an insecticide called chlorfenapyr and it still took months to get rid of them.

When I dealt with bed bugs in my apartment a few years back the little bowls with talcum powder were really helpful. We put them on our bed as well as our couch. After we installed them the bugs got a bit hungrier and I was able to find one crawling on me in the middle of the day. My landlord was a jerk and we needed physical proof of bed bugs before he would do anything about it, so this was crucial in getting the heat treatment.  I'm jealous of the people who don't react to the bites. I got welts larger than quarters on my body that itched like crazy. In case anyone needs to know, rubbing the inside of a banana peel on the bite will make the itching go away instantly. It's temporary, but still very much needed when you're dealing with them on a daily basis.

The only problem with just applying heat tho, is that A LOT of clothing and common items (like anything made of plastic) cannot tolerate much more than 100Â°F without being damaged. I don't even put sweaters in the dryer anymore because I've had a few shrink multiple sizes. I got rid of bud bugs in a matter of weeks. Get a spray bottle and rubbing alcohol 70% or more. Spray all crevices, mattresses, bed frames, everything, every day. Drench everything, doesn't matter what it is. It dries their exoskeleton instantly. Fun to watch how they instantly freeze.
I have actually tested the tempature way and it actually doesn't work if you already live in a hot climate in fact it makes them breed faster

Mark - question for you.  I'm in the hotel business and we work with ecolab - Ecolab handles any bed bug issues we've encountered.  What we've learned from them that heat treatment often leads to bed bugs running from the heat and going into any nook and cranny that they can to escape the heat.  Ecolab from what I've learned from them has developed products that eat the shell of the bed bug and have a residual effect.  I'd be curious to see a segment with them as they are probably one of the nation's largest companies treating bed bugs.  I'd be curious to see how their products actually work in a laboratory setting.

Bed Bugs can't walk or climb on things wrapped in teflon plumbing tape, so If bed legs are wrapped in teflon tape then the bugs have to drop from the ceiling. Salt (dust, not granules) tends to accumulate in their systems and makes them even more susceptible to Diatomaceous Earth.

I had bed bugs about 5 years ago - compliments of the guy below me. I thought the bumps were because I have allergies and didn't figure out it was bed bugs for quite some time.  To get rid of them I took the entire condo up to 140 F (60 C) and held it at that temp for 4 hours.   It took almost 10 hours for the place to cool down enough to sleep in again. I spread diatomaceous earth in all of the cracks, outlets, and areas that lead to other condos (i.e. water pipes, drains, etc)  I still have the creeps at night if I think I feel something on me. These things are miserable little jerks to get rid of.
The bed bugs caught mark sleeping loose rip.
Got them in a hotel years ago, small infestation in one room so I took two space heaters, bypassed the thermostats and heated the room to 130, problem solved.  You do need to circulate the air and I did it for 8 hours to make sure the heat soaked into everything in the room and the floorboards and stuff.  Can't imagine dealing with an entire house of them.

Here is how a dryer works... the heating element gets the same amount of hot no matter the setting. The difference is how long the heating element stays on at one time. So even on medium, it should be ok. It's tough on material when you put the setting on HOT and the temperature stays hot for several minutes at a time. Medium lets it get hot, just not stay as hot for a long period of time... more intermittent. Great video!

If you have them in your apartment, there's no way to get rid of them. They migrate to and from adjacent units. Just move out. They hitchhike on shoes and luggage. The tell-tale signs they came with you are mosquito bites around your ankles and legs, when normally there are no mosquitoes around (winter time). If you're careful about those two entry points, you can stop their infestation before it's too late. Safe traveling everyone!

You can't generalize everybody's situation like this.  If you live in a building with different apartments and all apartments are infested with bedbugs, but they are treated at different times you end up never resolving the issues about bed bugs. They jump from unit to unit in a building and the problem never goes away.  We lived in a building like this.  Our unit was treated, but the other units were NOT TREATED AT ALL.  As soon as the minimum period of treatment was done, and as soon as all of our clothes were specially treated, we moved out and found another building where we lived as far away as possible from humidity and from ground level.  One of the worst experiences our family needed to go through.  I wouldn't wish it on anybody.

Your steamer need to have enough pressure to penetrate the fabric. Some furniture has deeper recesses and require more pressure to penetrate. Part of the reason you need pressure is not just deeper penetration but because the temperature is at the top of the steamer. The deeper or further from that tip the lower the temperature is going to be when it reaches bed bugs.

One of the main things you missed about Diatomaceous earth, Is that its microscopic shards of glass, that slice and cut bugs. And it works into the soft joints, cuts them and then the bug bleeds out. It is interesting because it doesn't have the effect on mammals, it specifically deadly to bugs in general.

My only question is about the freezing them. Didn't the guy say if they get cold they can last up to 300 days?
We had some about 6 months ago in my son's bed.  I bought a steamer and did the mattress and every nook and cranny of his bed, which was on a wood frame with drawers beneath. Most of them were living on the most difficult to reach spot, which means I missed them on the first attempt.  2nd time around I flipped the frame over to get everything.  They had also found their way into my room.  I was very sensitive to their bites, whereas my wife showed no signs.  Because of this I didn't realize my bites were from bed bugs because I figured she would have them too.  Anyway, after steaming the beds and the carpet around them, steaming out couch, and washing and drying everything on high heat, I've not seen a bed bug in about 6 months.  I really didn't think I'd be able to take care of them but it worked out.  Something not touched on in this video, but I suspect they don't live very far from your bed.  It's not like they're gonna want to have to travel across the house to feed.  So unless the infestation is really bad, just getting the areas within a few feet of the bed or couch where they're likely to feed is probably going to work...unless I just got lucky.
You being in my hometown of NJ, to a University I know very well is so surreal. One day our paths will cross I am sure of it!

Isn't diatomaceous earth also extremely sharp from the perspective of a small insect, which creates cuts from which fluids exit their bodies? Fluid also deactivates the diatomaceous earth, so it's important to reapply if you notice that it begins to appear wet.

I had bed bugs 7 years ago and it was so terrifying to me. I have a reaction to their bites and because of that, I was getting really terrible sleep for weeks. My hands had these bumps all over them and my parents thought I was having some sort of allergic reaction to something in the house. My parents "quarantined" off my room and put Diatomaceous Earth all around my bedroom and the surrounding rooms, and I just didn't go into my room for months and starved them out. After we got rid of them, I swore that sometimes I could still feel them crawling on me at night, even though I knew they were gone.

Super wild bed bug facts: #1. They can survive up to 300 days without feeding if the environment is relatively cold. #2. They don't carry/transmit any diseases. #3. They are attracted to vertical objects. #4. Today, every 1 in 1000 houses have bed bugs in them (before 1950, every 1 in 3 houses has them). #5. They reproduce through something called traumatic insemination.

From what I read, roaches clean the diatomaceous earth on their legs and get it on their mandibles, which tears apart their mandibles and mouths. I wonder if the same can happen for bed bugs.
Back when I had an apartment infestation, I lightly dusted with the diatomaceous earth every few days but also made a carbon dioxide trap, mostly to monitor population and verify if my efforts were working. Making the trap is a simple build that may appeal to viewers of this channel. A 2L pop bottle, some tubing, a mug, masking tape, yeast and water.

After watching this video, life became more manageable as there is now one less thing for me to worry about. Thanks, Mark and team!
Back in the 90's I stayed in a backpackers in Rawalpindi Pakistan, my mattress had bed bugs, I complained to the manager who gave me a powder to sprinkle on the mattress that he said would solve the problem. I read the box to see what this magic powder was, and one of the ingredients was Dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane, or more commonly known as DDT. So I decided not to use that solution. Another person staying at the backpackers advised me to put my mattress out into the sun and this had the desired effects, no more bed bugs.  I'm surprised this was not mentioned as a solution in the video as many warmer countries use this as a way to manage bed bugs. If it's sunny and over 25C then the surface of objects exposed to the sun will easily go over 50C a cars interior will go well over 60C on a sunny 25C day.

I had an issue with bed bugs a few years ago, and I had a very severe reaction to them.  It took almost two years to get rid of them! Having a strong reaction turned out to be a positive, because I know what to look for now

A fact about bed bugs rarely seen mentioned is bed bugs, unlike moths, hate wool. Also they won't go into or bite within areas of the human body where hair grows. The same is true for mites. Cedar wood repels moths but it's unknown at this point if it also repels bed bugs.

A few years back we thought we had bed bugs, after much hassle of cleaning and heating and using DE we found out we didnâ€™t have bed bugs but rather bat bugs. They are closely related and are very hard to tell the difference between. Bat bugs will feed on humans but require a bat host to stay alive and reproduce. So get rid of the bats in the attic, get rid of the bugs. My husband had no reaction to their saliva, I on the other hand did, (very itchy red patches) and being pregnant at the time I was very happy to be rid of those pests.

My family got bed bugs and we ended up putting a lot of things in the attic. Luckily all our beds already had bed bug sheets to prevent them getting to the mattress. Since we planned to renovate the upstairs, we decided to do that then. Luckily it happened during summer so we out the stuff in our garage attic (it's a detached building to our house) and within a week for super hot weather, it was fine. Some things were bagged in our freezer but most stuff got fixed with a couple runs through the dryer or weeks to months to over a year in our garage. Fixed it without needing to call anyone. We also renovated though, removing all the carpet in our house, beds off the floor and away from walls. Fixed it mostly.

Honestly fascinating and informative. Colour me curious though how effective would this be for carpet beetles? -guess whos unfortunately allergic to them.-
Great video Mark, thank you. We had a moderate infestation that took about 3 years to completely get rid of. We threw out 2 mattresses, 1 bedframe, a couch, and a living room chair, pulled up a rug, and refinished a bedroom before it was all over. We didn't know it at the time, but they were living behind the Wainscot molding around the bedroom wall. They were brought in the suitcase of one of my daughter's friends, who got them from her brother, who got them from a camping lodge. We found out that they were bedbugs because my daughter had a strong allergic reaction, as I did as well. Itchy red splotches. My daughter developed a bit of insomnia, and that's how we finally caught them in action! And then IT WAS WAR! Fortunately, we had a few friends in the exterminator business and got some solid help. Diatomaceous dirt and Steri-Fab were applied to the formally infected and cleansed areas, along with the personal application of a combination of tea tree oil, eucalyptus oil, and mint oil helped us. Even if the oils had no effect on the bedbugs, we at least felt better. We also put our bedding and night clothes  through the dryer every  morning.
Also putting sticky pads under your chair and bed legs will catch them from trying to climb up vertical surfaces

AND YOU FORGOT TO STUDY SUNLIGHT! Or as I call it, DSL (Direct Sun Light) This was why people in the 50's and 60's still dragged their furniture outside for a cleaning. A summer's day out in the sun for entire bed sets was a regular thing. Bedbugs in sudden sunlight actually recoil and fumble after the shade.

I did have a small infestation by taking beds from a badly infested house. I did use raid, using bed bags, and throwing everything in the dryer or the wood frames out in the sun on a 115 degree day. It took a few months but eventually we erradicated the infestation and know not to take anything without inspecting it thoroughly first. I know what to look for from working in a hotel and undergoing bed bug training.  We haven't had an issue with them since and if and when we travel I always check the room before settling in. I'm one of those that react horribly to the bites and they cause a lot of emotional, and mental anguish as well as physically painful bites. You become super paranoid, I have woken up in the middle of the night, tore apart my bedding after feeling a bite to find the culprit and dispatch it asap. We have the most cheapest (deadliest) solution: Aluminum Phosphate tablets. only issue is that these smells horrendous and are extremely hazardous to breathing too. So sealing up the apartment for 2/3 days gives 100% mortality rate. It literally costs us $2.00 with no professional services needed.

Dealt with my parents home having a massive infestation.  My parents did not have reactions, but my wife and to a lesser amount, me, had reactions.  This went on for years, including one total housecleaning and disposal of numerous furniture pieces, they just kept coming.  I finally put my foot down and arranged for professional erradication.  I did most of the house cleaning for prep, and it was awful!  The bed was very much like the example in the video, the space behind the outlets was packed.  I literally had a two foot diameter and 3 inch hight pile of dead bedbugs on the floor.  I emptied all their clothes storage and ran everything through the dryer at max heat, bagged them up, and put them outside, where most have been for over a year now.   More used clothes were dryed on high, then washed in hot water, then dried on high again.  Items in drawers were packed up and vacuumed bagged, then put in the garage for over a year.  The exterminator went through with some newer chemicals that supposedly stayed active for up to three months that he applied after steaming.  It took two sessions since the chemicals are not effective against eggs farther back in the walls.  There has been no reported activity since.

It took about two weeks to eliminate them.

Yes a new Video
If you currently have bed bugs and can't afford an exterminator:   Follow Mark's suggestions with the mattress, vacuum, clothes, outlets etc. Make sugar yeast traps with a soda bottle, yeast, sugar, water and a straw. Mix contents in bottle,  focus the straw out of the top of the bottle into a porcelain or glass dish with diatomaceous earth inside and a little ramp leading the bugs into the dish. Make sure to push your bed away from the wall and put glass or porcelain bowls under the legs of your bed with diatomaceous in each of the bowls (you can do this to your couch too). An extra step for your bed is to put painters plastic under your mattress or on top of your box spring with a foot of excess around the sides. If you have pets, clean their bedding regularly and put yeast traps where they sleep if crated. These steps worked for me when I had bed bugs years ago. It was a psychological nightmare to deal with and I spent hours and hours researching the best methods to stop them.

I worked at a summer camp and we would get a bedbug infestation in one of the cabins almost every week. We had a giant metal container with a heater (it didn't have to work hard in the Texas summer) and we'd have to put everything in the cabin in there and let it sit for a couple of hours while our maintenence guy put that silica powder in the cracks of the walls. It was always pretty effective but every week some kid would bring it from home and we'd have to go again.

Mark is extremely fortunate to not experience a bad bite reaction. I had a short stint with these hellish pests, and let me tell you. When Iâ€™d wake up to a bite or 2, it was a stinging itch of a sensation, and after the bite, the rash was closer to poison ivy, than it was a mosquito bite. Trust me when I say, this bug will have you pulling your hair out!!! Yuck! Iâ€™m getting uncomfortable just remembering it all.
I tried the diatomaceous method, and placing traps at the legs of my bed worked, but I also added another method where I applied scabies medication all around my body and let the bugs feed. All of these methods worked for my case, but my case was mild, I guess, because I couldn't find any bed bugs when I searched my room. However, I knew I had them with me because my skin is highly reactive to their bites, and after I applied the scabies medication, I found two of them dead on my bed. Anyway, for those who are reactive to bed bugs like me, you may want to try FUCICORT cream. I've tried all sorts of essential oils and creams, but they didn't work, and only this cream worked.

16:45
This was probably the most useful video I watched on youtube in 10 years!
So, back when I was in college, my roommate brought bed bugs back from a trip. When I went to the hardware store to buy all the labeled chemicals, a professional exterminator walked past and politely informed me that none of them would work. He also directed me to the diatomaceous earth. BUT What he told me to do was surround the beds or bed posts with it and continue to sleep in those beds for 3 months. That way, the bugs would HAVE to pass over the diatomaceous earth in order to eat. If no one was sleeping in the beds then the bugs would travel to another room/apartment to find blood.  I went to bed every night knowing I was a bait buffet for the nasty, smelly bugs. And woke up every morning with red itchy bumps in rows.   It did work.  I also cooked my clothes in the dryer and vacuumed the cracks and crevices and all the other cleaning advice you gave (except I didn't think to use steam). When I moved at the end of that school year I didn't take a single bed bug with me.

Great Video! I've been told by frequent travelers that you can get infected with bedbugs anywhere you place your luggage. Hotel Vans, Airline overhead bins, airline luggage holds, luggage carousel, hotels, trunk of rental cars etc. The first thing I aways do upon entering a hotel room is to place my bags in the bathtub and check the mattress corners of the bed and sofa if there is one.  I've been lucky that I've never found any infestations or taken any bugs home in 50yrs of Travel, but I have heard horror stories so it's always on my mind to be careful.

See, I have really bad reactions to their bites. The last time one bit me I had a wheal the size of a softball, and actually needed antibiotics because the skin got infected. Previous times I've been bit, they leave giant, swollen, stinging welts.
Great Video, Mark.   I studied bed bugs after dealing with this for 2 years.  I used a method not mentioned in this video.  I placed a doggie dish upside down with talcum powder in the grooves to trap them.  I taped cloth around the perimeter of the upside-down doggy dish to give them something to climb up. To lure them to the dish, I placed a thermos with dry ice inside on top of the dish, closed the thermos and opened the nozzle.   This released CO2 (which as mentioned in the video is something the bed bugs are attracted to).  I kept the trap a couple feet from the bed.  I would replace the dry ice daily and stayed away from my home for a couple weeks.  This literally trapped all the bed bugs.  It takes a bit of effort and is inconvenient, but I have never had bed bugs again.  Also the video mentioned that 50% of people are not affected, but the reality is, it can be very depressing and embarrassing to live with them.  You also do not want people to visit you and then transfer them to their respective homes.  You can look up this solution in more detail by googling "dry ice bed bug trap".  I hope this helps someone and take care.

Only change I would offer is when you inspect a hotel bed, look under the BED SKIRT. The linens are washed all the time, so bed bugs are rarely in hotel linens. Bed skirts are rarely removed or washed, so bed bugs will shelter there during the day. They are most often found at the head of the bed, not the foot. Remember, they smell your breath, so they want to be close to your head.

Fun bed bug fact not mentioned, bed bugs co-evolved with humans, and human houses/beds are considered their native habitat. They evolved from bat-bugs, which lived in caves filled with bats, and when humans moved in, found that humans were tastier and heavier sleepers. Hence, bedbugs.

Diatomaceous silica, Bifenthrin, and a heat gun. Works flawlessly. Spread the silica between carpeted entry ways, underneath your bed, in nook and crannies, etc. Spray the Bifenthrin mixed appropriately with something like Fabreeze in the same areas. Then use the heat gun to attack all of your furniture top to bottom.

Very informative as a licensed pesticide applicator would definitely use insecticide powder that can be applied wet to extend the used you get out of the product. Most diatomaceous earth product do not last very long nor do they function very well after getting wet or are applied if humid areas.

To anyone dealing with bed bugs, buy space heaters and some thermometers. Crank the space heaters until all of your thermometers in the affected room reach 125/130. this saved me

Dealt with bed bugs for about 2 years, and still have phantom bites and worries about getting them again even though they are gone. After many professional treatments, only diatomaceous earth and steaming worked. I steamed all my pillows and cushions regularly, put the powder everywhere, especially under my tables and on table legs, around the legs of my bed. For a couple nights I slept on a yoga mat on the floor and put a ring of diatomaceous earth all around it knowing they'd come for me. I was getting bitten constantly both awake and asleep, and had red blisters everywhere - it was awful! But the bed bugs are finally gone now... nobody knows how to treat these things properly - my landlord and the people he hired to do all this gave so much bad advice! It was extremely frustrating. I'm sure that your video will save thousands of people a lot of headaches and financial struggles!

Great video Mark, thank you. We had a moderate infestation that took about 3 years to completely get rid of. We threw out 2 mattresses, 1 bedframe, a couch, and a living room chair, pulled up a rug, and refinished a bedroom before it was all over. We didn't know it at the time, but they were living behind the Wainscot molding around the bedroom wall. They were brought in the suitcase of one of my daughter's friends, who got them from her brother, who got them from a camping lodge. We found out that they were bedbugs because my daughter had a strong allergic reaction, as I did as well. Itchy red splotches. My daughter developed a bit of insomnia, and that's how we finally caught them in action! And then *IT WAS WAR!* Fortunately, we had a few friends in the exterminator business and got some solid help. Diatomaceous dirt and Steri-Fab were applied to the formally infected and cleansed areas, along with the personal application of a combination of tea tree oil, eucalyptus oil, and mint oil helped us. Even if the oils had no effect on the bedbugs, we at least felt better. We also put our bedding and night clothes  through the dryer every  morning.
I am now traumatized by Mark's bed bug reproduction explanation.

One thing I didn't hear you say about diatomaceous earth is the fact that it not only just absorbs moisture, it's also like a millions of micro razors.  It gets caught in the chitin plates of the insect and when they move around they also get cut up, helping hasten the leaking out their juices.
