Do roaches next.
We had bugs only in my bedroom. I looked up bed bug treatment and didn't want to spend 2k to treat the house. Every site said they wouldn't do room by room.   So I bought 2 $30 heaters from Walmart, an adapter for the high amp oven outlet, 2 10 gauge extension cords, 2 wifi plugs, 2 espressif32 boards and 2 quick connect temp sensors. I also had 5 high flow fans to circulate the air. I also used a metal cart just to hold the heaters.  I ran the extension cords to the oven outlet using the adapter. I plugged the heaters in using the wifi plugs. Then I used home assistant controlling the outlets to keep the sensor next to the heaters at 130Â°.   It did so by turning one or both heaters off at 128, then 130. And it would turn them back on when the heat went down to 127. I had the other sensor buried in a pile of clothes and let the whole thing run until the #2 temp sensor was 123. It took 18 hours... I sealed the door with masking tape to make sure nothing ran away.   I was ready to do it twice but I didn't end up doing it because my bites were consistent with only 1 or 2 and I found one of the bodies and squished it to be sure.

As a landlord, tenants brought a nasty, used couch onto the property and exposed the home to bedbugs.  I bought two sets of three different types of chemicals; A powder, a concentrated liquid, and an aerosol.  I forget how they applied all of them, but they took apart outlet covers, light switch covers took baseboards from the wall, and it took them 7+ hours!  They waited two weeks and did it again, eventually eradicating them.  Meanwhile, a friend of mine was in a posh Di$ney resort with her family and brought bedbugs to her home, costing them $5,000 to heat treat the home.  Those incidents made me very aware of bedbugs enough to educate myself on how to detect them.  When I travel, I inspect the bed, the mattress, the underside of bedside tables, behind the artwork, etc.  I taught my kids how to do that when they travel or spend the night at a friend's home.  I'm not overly cautious of bedbugs.  I'm overly cautious about spending $5,000+ to rid my home of bedbugs!  ðŸ¤£

I have used diatomaceous earth to eradicate flea infestations. The key part of the process is to NOT vacuum up the diatomaceous earth too soon after working it into the carpet. Give 14 days for any eggs to hatch so the new offspring suffer the same fate as the progenitors. I've never had bed bugs, but I have seen them and thought they were small ticks. Except ticks are arachnids and have 8 legs. Bedbugs are insects and have 6 legs.

Our experience lasted around 6 months and we were not sure until we ended up finding one and after that I used a tempo dust to get rid of my bugs. We didnâ€™t let anyone come to our apartment and when my sister did bring anyone over we made sure to let them know that we have had a couple and passed the info on about washing and drying their clothes in hot water and the heat of the dryer. The fear is valid and real!  Mark is so lucky this is his first experience with bed bugs. My husband and I got them from apartment neighbors twice (about three years apart) and it was awful. I'm really allergic but my husband doesn't react at all. So the first time we got them, I was getting huge welts and we didn't find them for over a month even while looking. We successfully moved twice after our infestations were getting under control. Bagging and hot drying or steaming all clothing and fabrics. Throwing out some upholstered furniture. Diatomaceous earth along wall edges. The bed post feet with baby powder helped catch bugs trying to get on our bed or get off. So glad to no longer be living in large apartments. Let's hope bed bugs never evolve well enough to protect themselves from Diatomaceous earth.

Bounce dryer sheets works. I was waking up with 3 patterned bite marks each morning. Laid down Bounce sheets between my mattress and the bottom half, my pillows, etc.  Not just a few but covered almost all areas & the bites stopped. I think that since they live in & on the mattress, the smell is too strong.  After a year, new ones are replaced.
It took all of my willpower to watch this video
Here's how I got rid of them....get rid of your bed, put a sleeping bag on on the floor, place a perimeter of double stick tape around the sleeping bag (leave a foot of two of space so you don't roll into it when you're sleeping).   As they bed bugs come to eat they cross the tape barrier with ease but on their way back their bellies are too fat and get stuck on the tape every time. I was able to get all of them without melting down my kitchen. I was also surprised to find that there were multiple varieties that had infested the apt.

I no longer live in that awful place and thankfully can afford a much better home now, but still today if I feel a slight rubbing or tickle on my skin I jolt awake in the middle of the night and start swatting.

11:42 So it is argued that traumatic insemination in most insects evolved in response to compete with impregnation defense systems of female bugs or genetic warfare tactics like mating plugs.  However, most bugs that do this still have traditional mating.  Bed bugs, I think, are the only bug that solely use T.I to procreate. Maybe they've been doing it for so long that their genes just forgot how to do it the normal way? No idea.

The best solution for eradicating bedbugs is quite similar to how Borax obliterates ant colonies.   Bedbugs with Diatomaceous =  Dehydration by sticking to them and transferring to other bedbugs. Ants with Borax = They get tons of cuts and end up drying out/dying and transfer it to other ants.    Pro-tip: If you have an ant problem, a Borax based ant bait (such as Terro) is the best solution. As it wipes out entire colonies.

I've been treating for bedbugs for a very long time. Unless it is an obvious long term infestation (visible multiple bugs and defecation everywhere)I inspect the premises at a macro level. All eggs and bugs get vacuumed and specialised chemicals get used to secure against future infestation.
While working at a homeless shelter, I'd always have rubbing alcohol in a spray bottle with me and would spray all my stuff before entering my home. Luckily, I never caught them. Not sure if it's because it was rubbing alcohol or if it was because of the scent of rubbing alcohol though ðŸ¤”

Diatomaceous earth and Boric Acid saved me from a matured German Cockroach infestation within weeks. If you know about these, they're notoriously difficult to get rid of because of how quickly they reproduce. The fact the Diatomaceous Earth is just as effective for bed bugs does not surprise me at all. The best part is the Earth is non toxic and Boric Acid is extremely low toxic to humans.

Mark, here is some distilled advise from my experience; don't trust the proclamations of authorities.   Any human parasite can spread disease or synergistic coinfections, some of which are yet to be recognized by the medical community.  In terms of medication resistance; canine roundworms are now totally immune, and many human infectious Helminths are close to immunity.

One thing I've found works really well at eradicating pretty much any infestation of bugs with exoskeletons is burning a bunch of trimethyl borate. When it burns the smoke contains loads of very fine, anhydrous boric acid crystals which settle on to almost every surface in the house and act like the diatomaceous earth. ALSO one thing people should know! If you find a bed bug in your bed but not bites the next morning, still check all clothes/belongings and donâ€™t assume you were not bitten. People can have delayed reactions to bites by up to 2 weeks. I was bitten by a bed bug in a hotel once and didnâ€™t have bites and didnâ€™t think of it (still searched all my belongings, but just thought I had no reaction), but then ended up waking up with several bites all across my body a week and a half later!!! So do know that people can have delayed reactions, and it does not necessarily mean you were bitten that very night they appeared!!!

Another fun fact about bedbugs. Just one of the several reasons we gave seen a resurgence of them is because for years people spent trying to eradicate one of the bedbugs nemesis ~ and that is cockroaches. Yes, cockroaches actually feed upon bedbugs.   You know it's bad when even a roach doesn't like you.  I'd rather not deal with either of them but fou d out that fun and disturbing fact while researching bedbugs for a work project.

There's only one solution to a bed bug problem: burn everything they've touched, and everything that has touched anything they touched. They spread and they can't be exterminated. Poison, "steam," isolation, none of it works, and anything you bring that has had contact with them will spawn new nests, even if you never see any on the item.

Diatomaceous earth works two ways, not just one.  The other way involves their shape.  They are very sharp and jagged, and get between the plates of the bugs' exoskeleton and cut the membranes. That also causes them to leak fluids and dehydrate even faster.   Boric acid is extremely effective on roaches, but also somewhat effective on bedbugs.  It works because bugs tend to act like cats when cleaning themselves.  The powder gets all of them (like Diatomaceous earth does) and as they try to get it off they end up ingesting some of it and it eats holes in their digestive systems.  But bedbugs feed through a tube, so it's less effective than with roaches.
Nevrr watching this video

thank you so much. i have been dealing with these things since December. i vacuumed and sprayed, at first it seemed to work but last yesterday i found more. I've been meaning to get some diatomaceous earth

I had a terrible problem with an apartment I lived in 3 years ago having a massive bed bug infestation. The owners of the building knew about the issue and never properly treated it so the bugs would just go from unit to unit over apparently decades from what I eventually found online in reviews for the apartment. ALWAYS read up before you move into shared living situations. Save yourself the time and money. People always talk about bad tenants and not enough about predatory landlords.
For defense, also donâ€™t buy previously owned upholstered furniture.  And be very careful bringing public library books into your home as bedbugs often hitchhike in their spines.  I got a mild infestation of bedbugs and it was a nightmare getting rid of them.  Cimexa works like diatomaceous earth, and Bedlam II Plus in combination finally won the war.  But it took a little over a year to win it because thereâ€™s so much bad information online about bedbugs.  It took a while to learn what would really work and what was nonsense. Mark Rober Fun fact about cockroaches: Did you know that Cockroaches clean themselves after touching a human, but it's not because they find people filthy. You won't see a cockroach frantically trying to clean off a human smell or avoiding us because of some dreaded human bacteria. Instead, they'll clean themselves after contact with any predator.

markwober
PROTIP for if you need to draw bed bugs out and get them to go to a specific place, such as a spot with lots of diatomaceous earth: dry ice! worked like a charm when i had to fight an infestation once. the dry ice gives off carbon dioxide as it evaporates which makes them think food is breathing nearby. stick a chunk in a plastic bowl, surround with DE, and leave it overnight. within a week of doing this every day, my problem was solved. i couldn't draw them out with my own body because i'm allergic to these suckers so the dry ice was a godsend.

One time I stupidly took in a piece of ally-found furniture. Turns out it was infested with bedbugs, and I had to deal with that for several months. Here is what I did: I used a bulb syringe aspirator to puff diatomaceous earth into all the nooks and crannies of my room. This rough material can damage their exoskeletons and desiccate the bugs. It took a while, but eventually I got it under control. BTW I threw out that furniture asap.

The hotels/motels here in Vegas commonly have bed bugs...  Hotels/Motels won't say anything if they have them btw (bad for reviews/profit margins)..  Fun fact about about the American Cockroach.. They can reproduce by parthenogenesis (Thelytokous parthenogenesis) IE no male needed (like aphids)..
2:25 Bed bugs don't have ears, they cannot hear you 15:05.
I have 5 litres of bedbug killer pesticide just sitting in my house because I got rid of the heavy infestation of bedbugs by a very simple method: plastic. One of my children developed rushes and we ended up taking him to the doctor as we wondered what was happening to him. The prescription didn't work. After a while he changed bedrooms but the rushes got worse. I eventually asked his brother to check pictures of bedbugs on the Internet and then check his bed so that if he saw bedbugs he would recognise them. He confirmed the presence of bedbugs. I spent a lot of money buying sprays and a sprayer and vacuuming mattresses but they spread to every room, curtains, chairs. My breakthrough came when I implemented an idea I bumped into on YouTube: The guy said plastic works. The large one used by painters to protect floors from paint splashes. I vacuumed mattresses and encased them in large plastic sheets. I then covered the beds making sure the plastic overlapped the headboards and I taped the plastic behind the ends of the beads creating  barriers between people and the bedbugs. At last!!! Before I knew it, after some months, my son told me that there were no bedbugs and it was true. I will never again spend money on anything else to eradicate bedbugs. I just starved them to death.

Another defense tip! The same trick you used to monitor beds can be used in a trickier way! Metal pet feeding bowls that go outwards upwards, can be put under legs of beds or chairs (obviously not rolling ones unfortunately) to prevent the bugs from climbing up. because the dish is metal, it doesn't have any areas where the bugs can get a grip while climbing, and the angle prevents them from doing so naturally anyways.  (just make sure not to have your feet on the ground) (I tend to rest my feet on the top of the bowls.)

I had one tenant that said he was so exhausted from them biting him and keeping him awake and mentally drained that he was seriously considering just jumping off the balcony of the ten story building. He had lost his will to live from them. That year I spent 86k dollars dealing with them at the sites I over saw. They are horrific to get into your home. I know of someone that got them in their home and for just that one property they were in close to 30k dollars to get rid of them.

How ironic. When I worked as an exterminator for a large company the salesman went to a house in rural eastern Colorado.The inspector/ salesman concluded he found bed bugs covering the entire second floor. On arrival on our first meeting I noticed bugs under wall tapestries and in non bed areas. After further investigation they were not bed bugs. After microscope viewing of said bed bugs they were similar but not bed bugs. They were bat bugs living off the guano off over 75 bats living in the attic. After watching the bats leave the roof I suggested they cover the hole so they don't come back into into the attic. In turn he wanted all his money back only because he never had bed bugs to begin with.

I somehow caught bedbugs once and I got rid of them so easily. I just put diatomaceous earth around each leg of the bed via little aluminium tart cups and then bought a 15$ mattress cover. I think I was asymptomatic to their bites as well since I never noticed them.  Bedbugs have a very distinct smell to me; smells like plasticine (or what I remember plasticine to smell like; haven't encountered it in a long time), or even certain types of clay. I used to have fleas, idk what happened to them  I remember looking up diatomaceous earthbut never bought it because I heard it could make you itch if you touch it  I tried so many options that I could get my hands on, repellent bracelets, cedar wood  I heard about the dish soap method, where it attracts the fleas and drowns them. Never tried it  I end up having this habit of moving my body vigorously or rub it whenever I feel something on my body. (I still feel things on my body but it's not fleas so idk why).   I remember in gym class, I was sitting on the floor and found a flea on my sock, and quickly, I snatched it between my fingers and moved my thumb a little to reveal half the body and used my other thumb's nail to rip it apart (I saw bloood gushing out). Fleas have a tough exoskeleton so I always make sure to rip them apart  Fleas are worse than bed bugs because they can jump super quick, so even if you see it, it doesn't mean you can always catch it

Twice I have moved into a studio apartment with an infestation and twice I got rid of all the bed bugs with a very very simple method. Double Sided Tape. Completely surround your mattress with a single line of double sided tape and when the bedbugs come for you at night they either get stuck on the tape on the way in or on the way out. Replace the tape every few days and in a week or two you will see a dramatic decline in their numbers and after a month or two you will rarely find a bedbug stuck to the tape. When you go a couple months without a bedbug getting stuck on the tape, you can be confident the bugs are gone.

I had to deal with these vampires when I was doing my masters . These creepy crawlers were everywhere (some student got it in), tried a lot of things and the things that worked for me are  1) throw away cheap furniture   2) wash and dry all the clothes , linens sleeping bags etc at the same time   3) spray 91% alcohol on all the corners( if not the whole house) , suitcases , pretty much everything remaining which were not clothes  4) for luggage bags I sprayed them with 91% alcohol and after 30 mins I  drenched them in the tub for a day and dried them in the balcony for a day. How to get rid of bedbugs (through personal experience)  Hot water for your things that can stand them. Like extremely hot water.   You will never find bedbugs in places in your house where no one spends a lot of time.  So focus on those areas (seats, beds, clothes, closets). Drench these areas and everything in them with scalding hot water.  Do this on e a week for 5 or so weeks.  Your bedbug problem solved. But you might ruin some of your stuff

As a General Manager of a high rise, raising the temp up for 10 hours and treating both the unit above and below with the 10 hour heat seemed to thwart the spread.  Hallways in the high rise were mandatory vacuumed daily.  Once a unit was identified as the initial source, we did monthly checks for 6 months after the heat treatment. Ugh.  Worst thing ever. I had bedbugs once, several years ago.  I ended up using diatomaceous earth, steam, insecticide + growth regulator, mattress enclosures, and a propane heater.  The heater was the most effective, I did one room at a time, 150 degrees for about 8 hours, then moved to the next room.  The combo worked, I haven't seen one since, and given how allergic to them I am (a bite itches for months) I'm pretty sure I'd notice. They're a massive pain to get rid of.
I remember getting stuck with infestation at someone's home. Couldn't sleep. Felt every single bite and went to war. Didn't get any sleep (Not even for 10 minutes) and finally felt relieved when I could go home.

The traumatic insemination in bed bugs reminded me of another Fun fact - I learned in my Biology class that Drosophila melanogaster (house fly species) also have males that, while mating, deal a lot of damage to the female that could lead to her dying shortly after laying her eggs. Apparently the seminal fluid that goes into the female causes the lowering of her immune system and causes increased chance of infections.

As a child I thought bedbugs were strictly fairytale creatures, just a kind of insect boogeyman. My mother would say "sleep tight, don't  let the bedbugs bite!" Then I moved to San Francisco and stayed in single resident occupancy hotel, called "SROs" hereabouts. Somehow, when I first saw one, I knew what it was. It was like seeing the tooth fairy. Except I knew I hadn't lost my mind. If I say the tooth fairy I'd be pretty sure I'd've lost my mind. Egads!  They might not carry disease, but the do induce a disorder! Waking up in the middle of the night to discover the walls crawling with them can give you BB PTSD!

My then-partner and I lived in a tiny room split off from the living room of a shared apartment, for a short time. The single bed we shared was crawling with bedbugs. That's where I learnt that we belonged to different groups along that 50-50% split... I never saw a single bite on me, whereas my ex was covered in red spots every morning. One thing of note. In Switzerland, and I imagine also a lot of countries, if you are renting your place, then the landlord is legally obligated to pay for bedbug exterminations. This is because infestations can come from anyone, including your neighbor. I think it's the most responsible thing to do in that case, in that country.

The easier solution is missed, and it won't cost you $4000. Kerosene heater, one is enough for a small room, several for larger rooms. Heat up the room, leave for a few hours, sweep through the house in this manner covering halls etc. with drop clothes to retain heat. I've treated several times in various places, and it works.

Important tip. Diatomaceous earth packaged for insect control often has insecticides in it which some folks can be sensitive to.  Food grade diatomaceous earth has no chemical additives and is safe around all mammals lizards and birds.

This video could have used a first aid section that includes a metal-frame bed that they can't climb. The finns used the steel-framed heteka bed to combat bedbugs in the 30s. The bigger ones have trouble climbing smooth surfaces like plastic but the nymphs seem to be better climbers. A sticky barrier around the legs might stop them and the blanket can't touch the wall or floor at any time.

One thing he didnâ€™t mention was that for a time the USA had virtually no bedbugs because of the widespread use of DDT, which we had to stop using because it was threatening birds with extinction. The end of DDT and the mass importation of products like bed frames from places like China is what brought bedbugs back.

I tried all of the big box store products to get rid of bedbugs. What I found is that those "bedbug remedies" were nourishment for the bedbug colony. I did find a legal product that worked and destroyed the colony. The store where I fount it was under constant investigation. Itâ€™s likely that the pest control companies felt threatened.

Look delicious.
8:17 Putting the sonic repellent device (and corresponding collection dish) about one foot from the non-sonic repellent ("control") collection dish is not very bright. In that configuration both dishes are fully awash in sound from the device, so if both dishes attract similar numbers of bedbugs you've proved nothing. However if you designed a test where one dish is subjected to sonic repellent noise, AND THE OTHER DISH IS NOT,  *_THAT'S_* how you scientifically determine the relative efficacy of the sonic repellent device.

Hi Mark!
my body shivering every 2 seconds
I had these and took care of it myself in 2 weeks by encasing my bed, waking up every night several times and getting them off the walls using duct tape, pulling my bed away from the wall and putting it on homemade traps filled with talcum powder and diatomaceous earth and vacuuming everyday.   I learned they were attracted to the person so figured it made no sense to sleep in another room and just bought brand new plain white sheets so I could see any blood they caused. I after about a week the number dropped to zero found, then I had a couple nights with a few, than by the end of the second week it was zero and I never saw them again.

He didn't explain it but the reason you do bed bug control once a week is because the eggs take a week to hatch and then several weeks for them to reach maturity. Once a week treatment for a month of two distrupts this cycle and prevents them from multiplying.
